sn36.22:0.2.eng: 3. The Explanation of the Hundred and Eight

sn36.22:0.3.eng: The Explanation of the Hundred and Eight

sn36.22:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, I will teach you an exposition of the teaching on the hundred and eight.

sn36.22:1.3.eng: And what is the exposition of the teaching on the hundred and eight?

sn36.22:1.4.pli: Dvepi mayā, bhikkhave, vedanā vuttā pariyāyena;
sn36.22:1.4.eng: Mendicants, in one explanation I’ve spoken of two feelings. In another explanation I’ve spoken of three feelings, or five, six, eighteen, thirty-six, or a hundred and eight feelings.

sn36.22:2.1.eng: And what are the two feelings?

sn36.22:2.3.eng: These are called the two feelings.

sn36.22:2.4.eng: And what are the three feelings?

sn36.22:2.5.pli: Sukhā vedanā, dukkhā vedanā, adukkhamasukhā vedanā—

sn36.22:2.7.eng: And what are the five feelings?

sn36.22:2.8.eng: The faculties of pleasure, pain, happiness, sadness, and equanimity. …

sn36.22:2.10.eng: And what are the six feelings?

sn36.22:2.11.eng: Feeling born of eye contact … ear contact … nose contact … tongue contact … body contact …

sn36.22:2.14.eng: And what are the eighteen feelings?

sn36.22:2.15.pli: Cha somanassūpavicārā, cha domanassūpavicārā, cha upekkhūpavicārā—
sn36.22:2.15.eng: There are six preoccupations with happiness, six preoccupations with sadness, and six preoccupations with equanimity. …
sn36.22:2.15.comm: Also at MN 137:8.1, MN 140:10.1 and AN 3.61:12.1. Outside of this context, upavicāra is only found in AN 6.52, where women are “preoccupied” with adornments and thieves are “preoccupied” with a hiding place.

sn36.22:2.17.eng: And what are the thirty-six feelings?

sn36.22:2.18.pli: Cha gehasitāni somanassāni, cha nekkhammasitāni somanassāni, cha gehasitāni domanassāni, cha nekkhammasitāni domanassāni, cha gehasitā upekkhā, cha nekkhammasitā upekkhā—
sn36.22:2.18.eng: Six kinds of domestic happiness and six kinds of renunciate happiness. Six kinds of domestic sadness and six kinds of renunciate sadness. Six kinds of domestic equanimity and six kinds of renunciate equanimity. …

sn36.22:2.20.eng: And what are the hundred and eight feelings?

sn36.22:2.21.pli: Atītā chattiṃsa vedanā, anāgatā chattiṃsa vedanā, paccuppannā chattiṃsa vedanā—
sn36.22:2.21.eng: Thirty six feelings in the past, future, and present.

sn36.22:2.22.eng: These are called the hundred and eight feelings.

sn36.22:2.23.eng: This is the exposition of the teaching on the hundred and eight.”

sn36.23:0.2.eng: 3. The Explanation of the Hundred and Eight

sn36.23:1.1.pli: Atha kho aññataro bhikkhu yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi. Ekamantaṃ nisinno kho so bhikkhu bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
sn36.23:1.1.eng: Then a mendicant went up to the Buddha, bowed, sat down to one side, and said to him:

sn36.23:1.2.pli: “katamā nu kho, bhante, vedanā, katamo vedanāsamudayo, katamā vedanāsamudayagāminī paṭipadā?
sn36.23:1.2.eng: “Sir, what is feeling? What’s the origin of feeling? What’s the practice that leads to the origin of feeling?

sn36.23:1.3.eng: What’s the cessation of feeling? What’s the practice that leads to the cessation of feeling?

sn36.23:1.4.pli: Ko vedanāya assādo, ko ādīnavo, kiṃ nissaraṇan”ti?
sn36.23:1.4.eng: And what is feeling’s gratification, drawback, and escape?”

sn36.23:2.2.pli: sukhā vedanā, dukkhā vedanā, adukkhamasukhā vedanā.

sn36.23:2.5.eng: Craving is the practice that leads to the origin of feeling.

sn36.23:2.7.pli: Ayameva ariyo aṭṭhaṅgiko maggo vedanānirodhagāminī paṭipadā, seyyathidaṃ—
sn36.23:2.7.eng: The practice that leads to the cessation of feelings is simply this noble eightfold path, that is:

sn36.23:2.8.eng: right view, right thought, right speech, right action, right livelihood, right effort, right mindfulness, and right immersion.

sn36.23:2.9.pli: Yaṃ vedanaṃ paṭicca uppajjati sukhaṃ somanassaṃ, ayaṃ vedanāya assādo;
sn36.23:2.9.eng: The pleasure and happiness that arise from feeling: this is its gratification.

sn36.23:2.10.pli: yaṃ vedanā aniccā dukkhā vipariṇāmadhammā, ayaṃ vedanāya ādīnavo;
sn36.23:2.10.eng: That feeling is impermanent, suffering, and perishable: this is its drawback.

sn36.23:2.11.pli: yo vedanāya chandarāgavinayo chandarāgappahānaṃ, idaṃ vedanāya nissaraṇan”ti.
sn36.23:2.11.eng: Removing and giving up desire and greed for feeling: this is its escape.”

sn36.24:0.2.eng: 3. The Explanation of the Hundred and Eight

sn36.24:1.1.pli: “Pubbeva me, bhikkhave, sambodhā anabhisambuddhassa bodhisattasseva sato etadahosi:
sn36.24:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, before my awakening—when I was still unawakened but intent on awakening—I thought:
sn36.24:1.1.comm: In this discourse, the Buddha recalls his reflection on feeling as part of his path to awakening. In the next, he describes the awakening itself.

sn36.24:1.2.pli: ‘katamā nu kho vedanā, katamo vedanāsamudayo, katamā vedanāsamudayagāminī paṭipadā, katamo vedanānirodho, katamā vedanānirodhagāminī paṭipadā?
sn36.24:1.2.eng: ‘What is feeling? What’s the origin of feeling? What’s the practice that leads to the origin of feeling? What’s the cessation of feeling? What’s the practice that leads to the cessation of feeling?

sn36.24:1.3.pli: Ko vedanāya assādo, ko ādīnavo, kiṃ nissaraṇan’ti?
sn36.24:1.3.eng: And what is feeling’s gratification, drawback, and escape?’

sn36.24:1.6.pli: sukhā vedanā, dukkhā vedanā, adukkhamasukhā vedanā.

sn36.24:1.9.eng: Craving is the practice that leads to the origin of feeling …

sn36.24:1.10.pli: yo vedanāya chandarāgavinayo chandarāgappahānaṃ. Idaṃ vedanāya nissaraṇan’”ti.
sn36.24:1.10.eng: Removing and giving up desire and greed for feeling: this is its escape.’”

sn36.25:0.2.eng: 3. The Explanation of the Hundred and Eight

sn36.25:1.1.pli: “‘Imā vedanā’ti me, bhikkhave, pubbe ananussutesu dhammesu cakkhuṃ udapādi, ñāṇaṃ udapādi, paññā udapādi, vijjā udapādi, āloko udapādi.
sn36.25:1.1.eng: “‘These are the feelings.’ Such was the vision, knowledge, wisdom, realization, and light that arose in me regarding teachings not learned before from another.
sn36.25:1.1.comm: This is describing the night of the Buddha’s awakening, using the same phrasing found in the first discourse (SN 56.11). | PTS edition does not number this as a separate discourse, hence its numbering is one-off from here to the end of the Saṁyutta.

sn36.25:1.2.pli: ‘Ayaṃ vedanāsamudayo’ti me, bhikkhave, pubbe ananussutesu dhammesu cakkhuṃ udapādi …pe… āloko udapādi.

sn36.25:1.3.pli: ‘Ayaṃ vedanāsamudayagāminī paṭipadā’ti me, bhikkhave, pubbe ananussutesu dhammesu cakkhuṃ udapādi …pe…
sn36.25:1.3.eng: ‘This is the practice that leads to the origin of feeling.’ …

sn36.25:1.4.pli: ‘ayaṃ vedanānirodho’ti me, bhikkhave, pubbe ananussutesu dhammesu cakkhuṃ udapādi …pe…

sn36.25:1.5.pli: ‘ayaṃ vedanānirodhagāminī paṭipadā’ti me, bhikkhave, pubbe ananussutesu dhammesu cakkhuṃ udapādi …pe…
sn36.25:1.5.eng: ‘This is the practice that leads to the cessation of feeling.’ …

sn36.25:1.6.pli: ‘ayaṃ vedanāya assādo’ti me, bhikkhave, pubbe ananussutesu dhammesu …pe…

sn36.25:1.7.pli: ‘ayaṃ vedanāya ādīnavo’ti me, bhikkhave, pubbe ananussutesu dhammesu …pe…

sn36.25:1.8.pli: ‘idaṃ kho nissaraṇan’ti me, bhikkhave, pubbe ananussutesu dhammesu cakkhuṃ udapādi, ñāṇaṃ udapādi, paññā udapādi, vijjā udapādi, āloko udapādī”ti.
sn36.25:1.8.eng: ‘This is the escape from feeling.’ Such was the vision, knowledge, wisdom, realization, and light that arose in me regarding teachings not learned before from another.”

sn36.26:0.2.eng: 3. The Explanation of the Hundred and Eight

sn36.26:1.1.pli: Atha kho sambahulā bhikkhū yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkamiṃsu; upasaṅkamitvā …pe… ekamantaṃ nisinnā kho te bhikkhū bhagavantaṃ etadavocuṃ:
sn36.26:1.1.eng: Then several mendicants went up to the Buddha, bowed, sat down to one side, and said to him:

sn36.26:1.2.pli: “katamā nu kho, bhante, vedanā, katamo vedanāsamudayo, katamā vedanāsamudayagāminī paṭipadā?
sn36.26:1.2.eng: “Sir, what is feeling? What’s the origin of feeling? What’s the practice that leads to the origin of feeling?

sn36.26:1.3.eng: What’s the cessation of feeling? What’s the practice that leads to the cessation of feeling?

sn36.26:1.4.pli: Ko vedanāya assādo, ko ādīnavo, kiṃ nissaraṇan”ti?
sn36.26:1.4.eng: And what is feeling’s gratification, drawback, and escape?”

sn36.26:1.6.pli: sukhā vedanā, dukkhā vedanā, adukkhamasukhā vedanā.

sn36.26:1.9.eng: Craving is the practice that leads to the origin of feeling.

sn36.26:1.11.pli: yo vedanāya chandarāgavinayo chandarāgappahānaṃ. Idaṃ vedanāya nissaraṇan”ti.
sn36.26:1.11.eng: Removing and giving up desire and greed for feeling: this is its escape.”

sn36.27:0.2.eng: 3. The Explanation of the Hundred and Eight

sn36.27:1.3.pli: Sukhā vedanā, dukkhā vedanā, adukkhamasukhā vedanā.

sn36.27:1.4.pli: Ye hi keci, bhikkhave, samaṇā vā brāhmaṇā vā imāsaṃ tissannaṃ vedanānaṃ samudayañca atthaṅgamañca assādañca ādīnavañca nissaraṇañca yathābhūtaṃ nappajānanti.
sn36.27:1.4.eng: There are ascetics and brahmins who don’t truly understand these three feelings’ gratification, drawback, and escape.
sn36.27:1.4.comm: I follow the assessment in Bodhi, Connected Discourses, note 258, that the inclusion of samudayañca atthaṅgamañca here must be an editorial oversight.

sn36.27:1.5.pli: Na me te, bhikkhave, samaṇā vā brāhmaṇā vā samaṇesu vā samaṇasammatā brāhmaṇesu vā brāhmaṇasammatā, na ca pana te āyasmanto sāmaññatthaṃ vā brahmaññatthaṃ vā diṭṭheva dhamme sayaṃ abhiññā sacchikatvā upasampajja viharanti.
sn36.27:1.5.eng: I don’t deem them as true ascetics and brahmins. Those venerables don’t realize the goal of life as an ascetic or brahmin, and don’t live having realized it with their own insight.

sn36.27:1.6.pli: Ye ca kho keci, bhikkhave, samaṇā vā brāhmaṇā vā imāsaṃ tissannaṃ vedanānaṃ samudayañca atthaṅgamañca assādañca ādīnavañca nissaraṇañca yathābhūtaṃ pajānanti.
sn36.27:1.6.eng: There are ascetics and brahmins who do truly understand these three feelings’ gratification, drawback, and escape.

sn36.27:1.7.pli: Te kho me, bhikkhave, samaṇā vā brāhmaṇā vā samaṇesu ceva samaṇasammatā brāhmaṇesu ca brāhmaṇasammatā. Te ca panāyasmanto sāmaññatthañca brahmaññatthañca, diṭṭheva dhamme sayaṃ abhiññā sacchikatvā upasampajja viharantī”ti.
sn36.27:1.7.eng: I deem them as true ascetics and brahmins. Those venerables realize the goal of life as an ascetic or brahmin, and live having realized it with their own insight.”

sn36.28:0.2.eng: 3. The Explanation of the Hundred and Eight

sn36.28:1.3.pli: Sukhā vedanā, dukkhā vedanā, adukkhamasukhā vedanā.

sn36.28:1.4.pli: Ye hi keci, bhikkhave, samaṇā vā brāhmaṇā vā imāsaṃ tissannaṃ vedanānaṃ samudayañca atthaṅgamañca assādañca ādīnavañca nissaraṇañca yathābhūtaṃ nappajānanti …pe…
sn36.28:1.4.eng: There are ascetics and brahmins who don’t truly understand these three feelings’ origin, disappearance, gratification, drawback, and escape. …

sn36.28:1.5.pli: pajānanti …pe… sayaṃ abhiññā sacchikatvā upasampajja viharantī”ti.
sn36.28:1.5.eng: There are ascetics and brahmins who do truly understand …”

sn36.29:0.2.eng: 3. The Explanation of the Hundred and Eight

sn36.29:1.1.pli: “Ye hi keci, bhikkhave, samaṇā vā brāhmaṇā vā vedanaṃ nappajānanti, vedanāsamudayaṃ nappajānanti, vedanānirodhaṃ nappajānanti, vedanānirodhagāminiṃ paṭipadaṃ nappajānanti …pe…
sn36.29:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, there are ascetics and brahmins who don’t understand feeling, its origin, its cessation, and the practice that leads to its cessation. …

sn36.29:1.2.pli: pajānanti …pe… sayaṃ abhiññā sacchikatvā upasampajja viharantī”ti.
sn36.29:1.2.eng: There are ascetics and brahmins who do understand …”

sn36.3:1.3.pli: Sukhā vedanā, dukkhā vedanā, adukkhamasukhā vedanā.

sn36.3:1.4.pli: Sukhāya, bhikkhave, vedanāya rāgānusayo pahātabbo, dukkhāya vedanāya paṭighānusayo pahātabbo, adukkhamasukhāya vedanāya avijjānusayo pahātabbo.
sn36.3:1.4.eng: The underlying tendency to greed should be given up when it comes to pleasant feeling. The underlying tendency to repulsion should be given up when it comes to painful feeling. The underlying tendency to ignorance should be given up when it comes to neutral feeling.
sn36.3:1.4.comm: The feelings themselves are inherent to the functioning of the mind, so they remain so long as the mind remains. But how we respond to feelings is conditioned by underlying tendencies, which can be abandoned.

sn36.3:1.5.pli: Yato kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhuno sukhāya vedanāya rāgānusayo pahīno hoti, dukkhāya vedanāya paṭighānusayo pahīno hoti, adukkhamasukhāya vedanāya avijjānusayo pahīno hoti, ayaṃ vuccati, bhikkhave, ‘bhikkhu niranusayo sammaddaso acchecchi taṇhaṃ, vivattayi saṃyojanaṃ, sammā mānābhisamayā antamakāsi dukkhassā’ti.
sn36.3:1.5.eng: When a mendicant has given up these underlying tendencies, they’re called a mendicant without underlying tendencies, who sees rightly, has cut off craving, cast off the fetters, and by rightly comprehending conceit has made an end of suffering.

sn36.3:2.3.eng: the underlying tendency to greed is there,

sn36.3:2.4.eng: if you don’t see the escape.

sn36.3:3.3.eng: the underlying tendency to repulsion is there,

sn36.3:3.4.eng: if you don’t see the escape.

sn36.3:4.1.eng: As for that peaceful, neutral feeling:

sn36.3:4.2.eng: he of vast wisdom has taught

sn36.3:4.4.eng: you’re still not released from suffering.

sn36.3:5.1.eng: But when a mendicant is keen,

sn36.3:6.2.eng: they’re without defilements in this very life.

sn36.3:6.3.eng: That knowledge master is firm in principle;

sn36.3:6.4.eng: when their body breaks up, they can’t be reckoned.”

sn36.30:0.2.eng: 3. The Explanation of the Hundred and Eight

sn36.30:1.1.comm: The PTS edition counts this as the opening paragraph of the next discourse.

sn36.30:1.3.pli: Sukhā vedanā, dukkhā vedanā, adukkhamasukhā vedanā—

sn36.31:0.2.eng: 3. The Explanation of the Hundred and Eight

sn36.31:1.1.pli: “Atthi, bhikkhave, sāmisā pīti, atthi nirāmisā pīti, atthi nirāmisā nirāmisatarā pīti;
sn36.31:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, there is rapture of the flesh, rapture not  of the flesh, and rapture even more spiritual than that not of the flesh.
sn36.31:1.1.comm: “Of the flesh” is sāmisa, used of a sacrifice where meat is included (Manu 4.131). This discourse offers a detailed analysis of this term.

sn36.31:1.2.pli: atthi sāmisaṃ sukhaṃ, atthi nirāmisaṃ sukhaṃ, atthi nirāmisā nirāmisataraṃ sukhaṃ;
sn36.31:1.2.eng: There is pleasure of the flesh, pleasure not of the flesh, and pleasure even more spiritual than that not of the flesh.

sn36.31:1.3.pli: atthi sāmisā upekkhā, atthi nirāmisā upekkhā, atthi nirāmisā nirāmisatarā upekkhā;
sn36.31:1.3.eng: There is equanimity of the flesh, equanimity not of the flesh, and equanimity even more spiritual than that not of the flesh.

sn36.31:1.4.pli: atthi sāmiso vimokkho, atthi nirāmiso vimokkho, atthi nirāmisā nirāmisataro vimokkho.
sn36.31:1.4.eng: There is liberation of the flesh, liberation not of the flesh, and liberation even more spiritual than that not of the flesh.

sn36.31:1.5.eng: And what is rapture of the flesh?

sn36.31:1.6.eng: There are these five kinds of sensual stimulation.

sn36.31:1.8.pli: Cakkhuviññeyyā rūpā iṭṭhā kantā manāpā piyarūpā kāmūpasaṃhitā rajanīyā …pe…
sn36.31:1.8.eng: Sights known by the eye, which are likable, desirable, agreeable, pleasant, sensual, and arousing. Sounds … Smells … Tastes …

sn36.31:1.9.pli: kāyaviññeyyā phoṭṭhabbā iṭṭhā kantā manāpā piyarūpā kāmūpasaṃhitā rajanīyā.
sn36.31:1.9.eng: Touches known by the body, which are likable, desirable, agreeable, pleasant, sensual, and arousing.

sn36.31:1.10.eng: These are the five kinds of sensual stimulation.

sn36.31:1.11.pli: Yā kho, bhikkhave, ime pañca kāmaguṇe paṭicca uppajjati pīti, ayaṃ vuccati, bhikkhave, sāmisā pīti.
sn36.31:1.11.eng: The rapture that arises from these five kinds of sensual stimulation is called rapture of the flesh.

sn36.31:2.1.eng: And what is rapture not of the flesh?

sn36.31:2.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu vivicceva kāmehi vivicca akusalehi dhammehi savitakkaṃ savicāraṃ vivekajaṃ pītisukhaṃ paṭhamaṃ jhānaṃ upasampajja viharati.
sn36.31:2.2.eng: It’s when a mendicant, quite secluded from sensual pleasures, secluded from unskillful qualities, enters and remains in the first absorption, which has the rapture and bliss born of seclusion, while placing the mind and keeping it connected.

sn36.31:2.3.pli: Vitakkavicārānaṃ vūpasamā ajjhattaṃ sampasādanaṃ cetaso ekodibhāvaṃ avitakkaṃ avicāraṃ samādhijaṃ pītisukhaṃ dutiyaṃ jhānaṃ upasampajja viharati.
sn36.31:2.3.eng: As the placing of the mind and keeping it connected are stilled, they enter and remain in the second absorption, which has the rapture and bliss born of immersion, with internal clarity and mind at one, without placing the mind and keeping it connected.

sn36.31:2.4.eng: This is called rapture not of the flesh.

sn36.31:3.1.pli: Katamā ca, bhikkhave, nirāmisā nirāmisatarā pīti?
sn36.31:3.1.eng: And what is rapture even more spiritual than that not of the flesh?
sn36.31:3.1.comm: “Even more spiritual than that not of the flesh” is nirāmisā nirāmisatarā.

sn36.31:3.2.pli: Yā kho, bhikkhave, khīṇāsavassa bhikkhuno rāgā cittaṃ vimuttaṃ paccavekkhato, dosā cittaṃ vimuttaṃ paccavekkhato, mohā cittaṃ vimuttaṃ paccavekkhato uppajjati pīti, ayaṃ vuccati, bhikkhave, nirāmisā nirāmisatarā pīti.
sn36.31:3.2.eng: When a mendicant who has ended the defilements reviews their mind free from greed, hate, and delusion, rapture arises. This is called rapture even more spiritual than that not of the flesh.

sn36.31:4.1.eng: And what is pleasure of the flesh?

sn36.31:4.2.eng: Mendicants, there are these five kinds of sensual stimulation.

sn36.31:4.4.pli: Cakkhuviññeyyā rūpā iṭṭhā kantā manāpā piyarūpā kāmūpasaṃhitā rajanīyā …pe…
sn36.31:4.4.eng: Sights known by the eye, which are likable, desirable, agreeable, pleasant, sensual, and arousing. Sounds … Smells … Tastes …

sn36.31:4.5.pli: kāyaviññeyyā phoṭṭhabbā iṭṭhā kantā manāpā piyarūpā kāmūpasaṃhitā rajanīyā.
sn36.31:4.5.eng: Touches known by the body, which are likable, desirable, agreeable, pleasant, sensual, and arousing.

sn36.31:4.6.eng: These are the five kinds of sensual stimulation.

sn36.31:4.7.pli: Yaṃ kho, bhikkhave, ime pañca kāmaguṇe paṭicca uppajjati sukhaṃ somanassaṃ, idaṃ vuccati, bhikkhave, sāmisaṃ sukhaṃ.
sn36.31:4.7.eng: The pleasure and happiness that arise from these five kinds of sensual stimulation is called pleasure of the flesh.

sn36.31:5.1.eng: And what is pleasure not of the flesh?

sn36.31:5.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu vivicceva kāmehi vivicca akusalehi dhammehi savitakkaṃ savicāraṃ vivekajaṃ pītisukhaṃ paṭhamaṃ jhānaṃ upasampajja viharati.
sn36.31:5.2.eng: It’s when a mendicant, quite secluded from sensual pleasures, secluded from unskillful qualities, enters and remains in the first absorption, which has the rapture and bliss born of seclusion, while placing the mind and keeping it connected.

sn36.31:5.3.pli: Vitakkavicārānaṃ vūpasamā ajjhattaṃ sampasādanaṃ cetaso ekodibhāvaṃ avitakkaṃ avicāraṃ samādhijaṃ pītisukhaṃ dutiyaṃ jhānaṃ upasampajja viharati.
sn36.31:5.3.eng: As the placing of the mind and keeping it connected are stilled, they enter and remain in the second absorption, which has the rapture and bliss born of immersion, with internal clarity and mind at one, without placing the mind and keeping it connected.

sn36.31:5.4.pli: Pītiyā ca virāgā upekkhako ca viharati sato ca sampajāno sukhañca kāyena paṭisaṃvedeti, yaṃ taṃ ariyā ācikkhanti: ‘upekkhako satimā sukhavihārī’ti tatiyaṃ jhānaṃ upasampajja viharati.
sn36.31:5.4.eng: And with the fading away of rapture, they enter and remain in the third absorption, where they meditate with equanimity, mindful and aware, personally experiencing the bliss of which the noble ones declare, ‘Equanimous and mindful, one meditates in bliss.’

sn36.31:5.5.eng: This is called pleasure not of the flesh.

sn36.31:6.1.eng: And what is pleasure even more spiritual than that not of the flesh?

sn36.31:6.2.pli: Yaṃ kho, bhikkhave, khīṇāsavassa bhikkhuno rāgā cittaṃ vimuttaṃ paccavekkhato, dosā cittaṃ vimuttaṃ paccavekkhato, mohā cittaṃ vimuttaṃ paccavekkhato uppajjati sukhaṃ somanassaṃ, idaṃ vuccati, bhikkhave, nirāmisā nirāmisataraṃ sukhaṃ.
sn36.31:6.2.eng: When a mendicant who has ended the defilements reviews their mind free from greed, hate, and delusion, pleasure and happiness arises. This is called pleasure even more spiritual than that not of the flesh.

sn36.31:7.1.eng: And what is equanimity of the flesh?

sn36.31:7.2.eng: There are these five kinds of sensual stimulation.

sn36.31:7.4.pli: Cakkhuviññeyyā rūpā iṭṭhā kantā manāpā piyarūpā kāmūpasaṃhitā rajanīyā …pe…
sn36.31:7.4.eng: Sights known by the eye, which are likable, desirable, agreeable, pleasant, sensual, and arousing. Sounds … Smells … Tastes …

sn36.31:7.5.pli: kāyaviññeyyā phoṭṭhabbā iṭṭhā kantā manāpā piyarūpā kāmūpasaṃhitā rajanīyā.
sn36.31:7.5.eng: Touches known by the body, which are likable, desirable, agreeable, pleasant, sensual, and arousing.

sn36.31:7.6.eng: These are the five kinds of sensual stimulation.

sn36.31:7.7.pli: Yā kho, bhikkhave, ime pañca kāmaguṇe paṭicca uppajjati upekkhā, ayaṃ vuccati, bhikkhave, sāmisā upekkhā.
sn36.31:7.7.eng: The equanimity that arises from these five kinds of sensual stimulation is called equanimity of the flesh.

sn36.31:8.1.eng: And what is equanimity not of the flesh?

sn36.31:8.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu sukhassa ca pahānā, dukkhassa ca pahānā, pubbeva somanassadomanassānaṃ atthaṅgamā, adukkhamasukhaṃ upekkhāsatipārisuddhiṃ catutthaṃ jhānaṃ upasampajja viharati.
sn36.31:8.2.eng: It’s when, with the giving up of pleasure and pain and the disappearance of former happiness and sadness, a mendicant enters and remains in the fourth absorption, without pleasure or pain, with pure equanimity and mindfulness.

sn36.31:8.3.eng: This is called equanimity not of the flesh.

sn36.31:9.1.pli: Katamā ca, bhikkhave, nirāmisā nirāmisatarā upekkhā?
sn36.31:9.1.eng: And what is equanimity even more spiritual than that not of the flesh?

sn36.31:9.2.pli: Yā kho, bhikkhave, khīṇāsavassa bhikkhuno rāgā cittaṃ vimuttaṃ paccavekkhato, dosā cittaṃ vimuttaṃ paccavekkhato, mohā cittaṃ vimuttaṃ paccavekkhato uppajjati upekkhā, ayaṃ vuccati, bhikkhave, nirāmisā nirāmisatarā upekkhā.
sn36.31:9.2.eng: When a mendicant who has ended the defilements reviews their mind free from greed, hate, and delusion, equanimity arises. This is called equanimity even more spiritual than that not of the flesh.

sn36.31:10.1.eng: And what is liberation of the flesh?

sn36.31:10.2.eng: Liberation connected with form is liberation of the flesh.
sn36.31:10.2.comm: This shows that sāmisa is a relative term. Compared to other feelings, absorption is “not of the flesh”, but compared to other liberations, the four absorptions are “of the flesh”. The commentary explains that this is so because they are still based on “form”, namely the reflection or counterpart experienced as a light or vision in the mind.

sn36.31:11.1.eng: And what is liberation not of the flesh?

sn36.31:11.2.eng: Liberation connected with the formless is liberation not of the flesh.

sn36.31:12.1.pli: Katamo ca, bhikkhave, nirāmisā nirāmisataro vimokkho?
sn36.31:12.1.eng: And what is liberation even more spiritual than that not of the flesh?

sn36.31:12.2.pli: Yo kho, bhikkhave, khīṇāsavassa bhikkhuno rāgā cittaṃ vimuttaṃ paccavekkhato, dosā cittaṃ vimuttaṃ paccavekkhato, mohā cittaṃ vimuttaṃ paccavekkhato uppajjati vimokkho, ayaṃ vuccati, bhikkhave, nirāmisā nirāmisataro vimokkho”ti.
sn36.31:12.2.eng: When a mendicant who has ended the defilements reviews their mind free from greed, hate, and delusion, liberation arises. This is called liberation even more spiritual than that not of the flesh.”

sn36.31:13.5.eng: The Linked Discourses on feeling are complete.

sn36.4:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, when an unlearned ordinary person says that

sn36.4:1.2.eng: there’s an abyss under the ocean,
sn36.4:1.2.comm: While the Buddha routinely spoke of various heavenly or lower realms, he only uses the term pātāla (“abyss”) in metaphorical senses (SN 9.1:3.3, SN 1.44:1.4). Tālapuṭa refers to it as a place, but this is in a line of poetry referring to mythical dangers of the oceans (Thag 19.1:14.2). The “Abyss” in the Purāṇas is said to be the lowest of the seven nether realms, but it is no hell. Rather, it is the glorious, jewel-festooned city of the dragons, beneath which Viṣṇu dwells, and whose glories exceed even the heavens (Śiva Purāṇa 5.15; Agni Purāṇa 120.2; Nārada Purāṇa 1.3.38). Perhaps the Buddha rejected such a notion as incompatible with his cosmology.

sn36.4:1.3.pli: Taṃ kho panetaṃ, bhikkhave, assutavā puthujjano asantaṃ avijjamānaṃ evaṃ vācaṃ bhāsati:
sn36.4:1.3.eng: they’re speaking of something that doesn’t exist.

sn36.4:1.5.pli: Sārīrikānaṃ kho etaṃ, bhikkhave, dukkhānaṃ vedanānaṃ adhivacanaṃ yadidaṃ ‘pātālo’ti.
sn36.4:1.5.eng: ‘Abyss’ is a term for painful physical feelings.

sn36.4:1.6.pli: Assutavā, bhikkhave, puthujjano sārīrikāya dukkhāya vedanāya phuṭṭho samāno socati kilamati paridevati urattāḷiṃ kandati sammohaṃ āpajjati.
sn36.4:1.6.eng: When an unlearned ordinary person experiences painful physical feelings they sorrow and wail and lament, beating their breast and falling into confusion.

sn36.4:1.7.pli: Ayaṃ vuccati, bhikkhave, ‘assutavā puthujjano pātāle na paccuṭṭhāsi, gādhañca nājjhagā’.
sn36.4:1.7.eng: They’re called an unlearned ordinary person who hasn’t stood up in the abyss and has found no footing.

sn36.4:1.8.pli: Sutavā ca kho, bhikkhave, ariyasāvako sārīrikāya dukkhāya vedanāya phuṭṭho samāno neva socati, na kilamati, na paridevati, na urattāḷiṃ kandati, na sammohaṃ āpajjati.
sn36.4:1.8.eng: When a learned noble disciple experiences painful physical feelings they don’t sorrow or wail or lament, beating their breast and falling into confusion.

sn36.4:1.9.pli: Ayaṃ vuccati, bhikkhave, ‘sutavā ariyasāvako pātāle paccuṭṭhāsi, gādhañca ajjhagā’ti.
sn36.4:1.9.eng: They’re called a learned noble disciple who has stood up in the abyss and found a footing.

sn36.4:2.3.eng: that arise and sap your vitality;

sn36.4:2.4.eng: if you tremble at their touch,

sn36.4:3.3.eng: you won’t stand up in the abyss

sn36.4:4.3.eng: that arise and sap your vitality;

sn36.4:4.4.eng: if you don’t tremble at their touch—

sn36.4:4.5.eng: you stand up in the abyss
